scopecontent.p: The Jñānārṇava is a Digambara Jain text on dhyāna (meditation, contemplation) by Śubhacandra, tentatively placed in the 11th century. The text, in 39 chapters, deals with four kinds of dhyāna, which Paul Dundas considers to be an influence from Kashmiri Śaivism (2002, 169).

This manuscript contains the first 12 chapters. It was perhaps originally a longer manuscript, but, on the last folio, the beginning of the 13th chapter has been deleted with yellow paste, in order to create the semblance of a complete manuscript.
There are also some intertextual comments, in red ink, which act as a very basic commentary. For example, verse 1.14 is preceded by “anya ca”, and verse 1.21 is preceded by “kiṃ ca” (2r).

Transcription conventions
() indicates unclear text. ¿? indicates sic erat scriptum or surplus text. […] indicates an ellipsis. Spaces added where possible. oḿ represents a Jaina oṃkāra.
